snippet: Older ultradistance runners push themselves to the limit, but a study finds they suffer no more injuries than other, shorter-distance runners.
abstract: University of California at Davis research finds, in long-term study of ultra-distance runners, that risk of injury in races longer than the standard 26.2-mile marathon is lower among runners who are older than age 50; factors for their success, even at an older age, include patience, caution and consistency of training habits.
lead_paragraph: Older ultradistance runners push themselves to the limit, but a study finds they suffer no more injuries than other, shorter-distance runners.
